error.unexpectedError: An unexpected error occurred. Please try again.

environmentalImpacts.optimalConditions: Optimal conditions for marine calcification and coral growth
environmentalImpacts.significantThreat: Significant threat to marine calcification processes
environmentalImpacts.supportsColdWater: Supports cold-water marine species and ecosystems
environmentalImpacts.optimalRange: Optimal range for diverse marine life
environmentalImpacts.mayStress: May stress some marine organisms if sustained
environmentalImpacts.highStress: High stress on marine ecosystems, coral bleaching risk
environmentalImpacts.goodTransport: Good for nutrient transport and marine ecosystem health
environmentalImpacts.challengingConditions: May create challenging conditions for some marine life
environmentalImpacts.adequateOxygen: Adequate oxygen for most marine organisms
environmentalImpacts.potentialHypoxia: Stress on marine organisms, potential hypoxia
environmentalImpacts.nutrientPoor: Indicates nutrient-poor surface waters typical of open ocean
environmentalImpacts.supportsProductivity: Phosphate levels support marine primary productivity
environmentalImpacts.supportsDiatoms: Silicate supports diatom growth and marine food webs
environmentalImpacts.healthyProductivity: Indicates healthy phytoplankton productivity and carbon fixation
environmentalImpacts.affectsTransport: Current direction affects regional water mass transport
environmentalImpacts.contributes: Contributes to regional circulation and mixing patterns
environmentalImpacts.withinExpected: Parameter within expected range for ocean health

contexts.normalOceanic: Normal oceanic pH supports healthy marine ecosystems
contexts.lowerThanOptimal: pH is lower than optimal but within acceptable range
contexts.concerningAcidification: pH indicates concerning ocean acidification levels
contexts.typicalHigherLatitude: Typical of higher latitude or deeper water masses
contexts.healthyTemperature: Healthy temperature range for most marine ecosystems
contexts.warmTropical: Warm but within normal tropical range
contexts.marineHeatwave: Unusually warm temperatures indicate potential marine heatwave
contexts.stagnantWater: Low current speeds may indicate stagnant water conditions
contexts.healthyCurrents: Healthy current speeds support marine productivity
contexts.affectsOrganism: Very strong currents can affect marine organism behavior
contexts.supportsDiverse: High oxygen levels support diverse marine life
contexts.healthyOxygen: Healthy oxygen levels for marine ecosystems
contexts.threatensLife: Low oxygen conditions threaten marine life
contexts.limitedUpwelling: Low nitrate levels suggest limited recent upwelling or mixing
contexts.suggestsUpwelling: Elevated nitrate suggests upwelling or riverine input
contexts.essentialNutrient: Phosphate is essential nutrient for marine phytoplankton
contexts.importantNutrient: Important nutrient for siliceous marine organisms
contexts.clearOcean: Typical of clear, deep ocean waters with low productivity
contexts.healthyPrimary: Shows healthy primary production in marine ecosystem
contexts.formsBase: Primary production forms base of marine food web
contexts.influencesNutrient: Flow direction influences nutrient and heat distribution
contexts.affectingTransport: Component of total current flow affecting marine transport

status.dataNotAvailable: Data not available for this location/date
status.requestTimedOut: Request timed out - server may be processing data
status.tryDifferent: Try a different location or date, or wait and retry

healthAnalysis.whyMatters: Why This Matters for Ocean Health

help.title: How to Use Ocean Data Explorer
help.subtitle: Your guide to exploring real-time ocean data and understanding marine ecosystems

overview.title: What is Ocean Data Explorer?
overview.description: This interactive globe allows you to explore real-time ocean data from scientific sources including NOAA, Copernicus Marine Service, and other oceanographic institutions.
overview.visualize: Visualize: Sea surface temperature, ocean chemistry, currents, and microplastic pollution
overview.analyze: Analyze: Ocean health indicators and ecosystem conditions
overview.explore: Explore: Historical and real-time oceanographic data worldwide

navigation.title: How to Navigate
navigation.clickGlobeDesc: Single-click anywhere on the globe to fetch ocean data for that location and display comprehensive analysis.
navigation.doubleClickDesc: Double-click to quickly zoom to a location and automatically fetch its ocean data.
navigation.dragRotateDesc: Drag to rotate the globe freely. Use mouse wheel or pinch gestures to zoom in and out.

controls.title: Control Panel (Top Left)
controls.dateSelectionDesc: Choose any date from 2003 to present. Recent dates (2020-2025) have the best data coverage. Data automatically updates when you change dates.
controls.randomLocationDesc: Jump to verified ocean locations with guaranteed data coverage
controls.randomDateDesc: Select a random date with good data availability
controls.randomBothDesc: Generate random date and location combination
controls.sstTextureDesc: Toggle sea surface temperature overlay on the globe
controls.microplasticsDesc: Show microplastic pollution data points as 3D spheres

dataPanel.title: Data Panel (Right Side)
dataPanel.temperatureDesc: Sea surface temperature, ice concentration, and temperature anomalies. Includes ocean health analysis and climate impact indicators.
dataPanel.chemistryDesc: pH levels, dissolved oxygen, nutrients (nitrate, phosphate), and carbon chemistry. Critical for understanding ocean acidification and marine ecosystem health.
dataPanel.currentsDesc: Current speed and direction, water temperature at depth, and salinity. Essential for understanding ocean circulation and marine habitat connectivity.
dataPanel.healthAnalysisDesc: Click the info icons next to each section to view detailed ocean health analysis, environmental impacts, and scientific context for the measurements.

footer.appName: Ocean Data Explorer â€¢ Real-time oceanographic data visualization
footer.dataSources: Data sources: NOAA, Copernicus Marine Service, and scientific research institutions

microplastics.title: Microplastic Pollution Analysis

descriptions.veryLow: Low concentrations with limited ecological impact

whatAre.title: What Are Microplastics?
whatAre.description: Microplastics are tiny plastic particles smaller than 5mm that result from the breakdown of larger plastic waste, synthetic clothing fibers, and industrial processes. They persist in marine environments for decades and accumulate in the food chain.
whatAre.sources: Sources: Plastic bottles, bags, fishing nets, synthetic textiles, tire wear.
whatAre.persistence: Persistence: Can persist in marine environments for 100+ years.

environmental.title: Environmental Impact
environmental.description: Microplastics affect marine ecosystems through multiple pathways, causing significant environmental damage.
environmental.marineLife: Marine Life: Ingestion by fish, seabirds, and marine mammals can cause intestinal blockage and malnutrition
environmental.foodChain: Food Chain: Bioaccumulation through the food web from plankton to top predators
environmental.oceanChemistry: Ocean Chemistry: Can transport harmful chemicals and affect marine chemical processes

health.title: Human Health Implications
health.description: Microplastics enter human systems primarily through seafood consumption and can have various health effects.
health.physicalEffects: Physical Effects: Inflammation, cellular damage, potential immune system disruption
health.chemicalTransport: Chemical Transport: Can carry toxic chemicals and additives into human tissues

measurement.title: Measurement Information
measurement.description: Microplastic concentrations are measured through water sampling and laboratory analysis using microscopy and spectroscopy techniques.

microplastics.footer: Microplastic analysis based on real-time data from multiple scientific sources.

description.temperature: Sea surface temperature is a critical indicator of ocean health, affecting marine ecosystems, coral reefs, and global climate patterns.
description.chemistry: Ocean chemistry parameters like pH, dissolved oxygen, and nutrients determine the health of marine ecosystems and their ability to support life.
description.currents: Ocean currents transport nutrients, heat, and marine life, playing a crucial role in maintaining healthy marine ecosystems.

importance.temperature: Temperature changes impact species distribution, coral bleaching, marine food webs, and ocean circulation patterns that regulate global climate.
importance.chemistry: Chemical changes affect marine organism survival, coral calcification, shell formation, and the entire marine food web structure.
importance.currents: Current patterns affect nutrient distribution, marine biodiversity, climate regulation, and the connectivity of marine habitats.

oceanHealth.whyMatters: Why This Matters for Ocean Health
oceanHealth.noDataMessage: {{section}} data is not available for this location and date.
oceanHealth.tryDifferent: Try selecting a different location or date to view {{section}} data.
oceanHealth.footer: Ocean health analysis based on real-time data from multiple scientific sources. Data reflects current conditions and may change with new measurements.
